Source-Channel Coding without CSI at the Transmitter
Transmission of Gaussian source without CSIT. Quasi-static block fading. Decoding is delay-limited. Channel is non-ergodic: separation is suboptimal. Transmitter knows the fading distribution.
Minimize expected distortion EH [D] of reconstruction. Squared error distortion. Power constraint P. Bandwidth ratio: b channel uses per source symbol.
Layered Broadcast Coding System Model
Gaussian source is successively refinable: Each layer successively refines the description in the lower layer.
Layered broadcast coding: Superposition coding: one layer for each fading state.
Receiver decodes the layers supported by the channel realization.
Undecodable layers are treated as noise.
Successive decoding is capacityachieving for single-antenna Gaussian broadcast channel.

Multiple-Layer Minimum Expected Distortion
Low SNR: Negligible improvement from having more layers.
High SNR: Distortion dominated by outage probability.
Low SNR: Quantized CSIT nearly as good as perfect CSIT.
High SNR: Quantized CSIT marginally better than no CSIT.

Conclusions
Transmission of a Gaussian source without CSIT. Layered broadcast coding with successive refinement source coding. Optimized power allocation for minimum expected distortion.
Two-layer power allocation: Allocate power to higher layer up to a power ceiling.
Multiple layers: Recursively apply two-layer optimization.
Continuous fading distribution: Limiting process as spacing between layers tends to 0.
Minimum expected distortion: At high SNR, large benefits from diversity.
